bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 7, 1952

div1.p: Hench suggests additional individuals to be invited to the dedication of Camp Lazear. He expresses concern about the restoration work on Building No. 1, fearing that it is replication instead of restoration. Hench requests further details about his involvement during the dedication ceremony and Science Academy Session.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 7, 1952
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
November 7, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
You will want the following addresses:
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Mr. James L. Hanberry
591 Summers Avenue
Orangeburg, South Carolina
Mrs. Robert P. Cooke
Whistle Creek
Lexington, Virginia
Mr. Gust E. Lambert
4718 Woodlawn Avenue
Chicago, Illinois

I have not corresponded with Mr. Lambert for three or four years. I hope
this address is correct.

I have today written all of them telling them that you want a photograph
of them. You did not say for what purpose you wanted it, for publicity
purposes related to the dedication of Camp Lazear or to be framed and hung
in the little building. If it is for publicity purposes you may want a
glossy print. If it is to hang in the building you will want a smooth
print, possibly with their autograph. I have told each of them that they
will be hearing from you immediately.

As I wrote you, Doctor Cooke has just died; therefore I wrote to Mrs. Cooke.
Regarding Lambert and Hanberry, neither one can afford to go to Cuba without
financial assistance. If you must choose only one, Hanberry would of course
be the one as he is now the only surviving volunteer

I just received two days ago the airplane photographs of Camp Lazear taken
from quite high up. I am very glad to have these but I am more anxious to
have some taken lower down, especially the tangential views which will be
taken later. I certainly appreciate your efforts regarding this.

I was a little dismayed to see from the photographs that you all decided to
remove all of the walling. Will that not make the present Building No. 1
almost a replica rather than a restoration? We know that the inner walls
were original, showing the tongued-and-grooved boards, also the sliding panels
and outer shutters must have been original. I am not sure how much of the
roof was original. Of course there was no ceiling. I do hope that you can
use part of the original walling or, if you can't use it outside, could you
erect a few of the original tongued-and-grooved panels inside as a demonstra-
tion of the original construction in one part of the room? I do hope also
you can reinsert the original sliding panel and shutters. I am indeed grateful
to you for saving me some of this wood as I am most anxious to have it. Since
I will be flying back, I will not be able to bring it back but I shall try to
make arrangements for someone to pack me a box and ship it to me by freight
or express.

Pedro, you say that you want me to talk for 8 or 10 minutes and I shall start
collecting my thoughts. Will my talk be at the dedication? I shall keep the
talk strictly limited to the allotted time. As I write it, I should like to
know what the name of the camp will be. Is it to be called Camp Lazear or
Parque Finlay or a combination of the two names, “Parque Finlay at Camp Lazear.”
As you know, I have been hoping that the name Camp Lazear could be maintained
and I assume that Building No. 1 will still be called Reed's Building No. 1.
The reason I ask is that I want to use the proper terms in my talk and not have
a conflict with the other talks.

You ask me to attend the Science Academy Session “on the 3rd night” where you
will be the principal speaker. I assume that you mean on the evening of
December 3. Will you please let me know at once whether this is correct? If
so, I shall plan to stay over that night and will attend the session with great
pleasure. I suspect that the speeches will be mostly in Spanish and I won't
understand them but I shall be happy to be there to honor those concerned. You
say that I should not forget my Finlay Medal. Will the affair be formal? Will
there be occasion for me to bring my dinner jacket or just a dark business suit?
What time will this affair be over in the evening? I had planned to take the
night plane from Havana to Chicago but perhaps I had better stay over until the
night of December 4.

Some months ago there seems to have been organized a Walter Reed Society sponsored
by the National Society for Medical Research. I know nothing about it. I
merely found a clipping on page 214 of the Journal of the American Medical
Association, January 19, 1952. The following are the officers and you might
wish to send them invitations:
Dr. Max Sadove, Head of the Department of Anesthesiology, University of Illinois,
Chicago, Illinois (President).
Dr. Clinton H. Thienes, Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology,
University of Southern California School of Medicine, Los Angeles,
California (Vice President).
Dr. Lloyd D. Seager, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, University of Arkansas
Fayetteville, Arkansas (Vice President)
Dr. John P. McGovern, Chief of the Outpatient Department, Children's Hospital
Washington, D. C. (Vice President).
Miss Betty Jenney, Research Associate, University of Illinois, Chicago, Illinois
(Secretary-Treasurer).

I do not know how extensive your invitation list is. Undoubtedly you are in-
viting other distinguished American physicians and perhaps U. S. Public Health
Officials. Have you in mind to invite the President of the American Medical
Association, Dr. Louis H. Bauer. His address is 131 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead,
Long Island, New York; also the President-Elect of the American Medical Associa-
tion, Dr. Edward James McCormick, 402 Madison Avenue, Toledo, Ohio. Dr. Morris
Fishbein is, I believe, one of the active members of an organization formed a
few years ago called the “Finlay Institute of the Americans.” I know nothing
about it. I merely read a little something about it somewhere. You might care
to invite Doctor Fishbein and some of his associates if the organization is
still active. His address is:5543 Blackstone Avenue, Chicago, Illinois.

I have a special reason for having a representative group invited and I have
talked to you about it before but I think it is now more important than ever.
When I see you we must discuss the next move. I still hope that now that you
and the Cuban government have made such a splendid beginning, it is time for
our American friends to start the ball rolling for the erection of a permanent
memorial building, in one room of which will be Building No. 1. The rest of
the building can be devoted to some public and useful venture, perhaps a
small public health unit. The more American doctors we can get interested in
all of this, the easier it will be to raise the necessary money. I assume you
are sending official invitations to the State Department and to the American
Embassy in Cuba. You will remember that Tom Spies and Mrs. Smith of F.I.M.
are also quite interested in the venture.

I hope that in thinking about foreigners, you don't forget to invite Miss
Rojas and Miss Cabrerra to the affair. It was Miss Rojas' father of course
who cooperated with Walter Reed in setting up the camp on the Finca San Jose.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
